title-group.article-title: A revision of the genus Coryssiphus Simon, 1903, with its transfer to Systariinae (Araneae: Miturgidae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
A revision of the genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
, with its transfer to Systariinae ( Araneae : Miturgidae )
JAN BOSSELAERS
Royal Museum for Central Africa, B 3080 Tervuren, Belgium
Ễ dochterland@telenet.be; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8306-3554

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
is redescribed and found to be composed of two species.
Coryssiphus unicolor Simon, 1903
is synonymised with
C. cinerascens Simon, 1903
, being the female of that species.
Coryssiphus praeustus Simon, 1903
and
C. cinerascens
are redescribed and the genus is transferred from Liocranidae to Miturgidae : Systariinae based on a number of somatic and genitalic characters. The peculiar presence of
Coryssiphus
in Africa is briefly discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Coryssiphus Simon, 1903
was described by
from the South African Cape Peninsula (“ Prom. Bonae Spei! ”). The genus was originally considered by Simon to be close to
Mesiotelus Simon, 1897
and
Scotina Menge, 1873
(
). Simon had two males and one female at his disposal, which he attributed to three different species. The larger male was described as
Coryssiphus praeusta Simon, 1903
, soon thereafter corrected to
C. praeustus ( Simon 1903b )
, since the gender of
Coryssiphus
is masculine and
praeustus
(meaning burnt, coloured as charred wood) is an adjective. The smaller male,
C. cinerascens Simon, 1903
was considered to differ from
C. praeustus
by its size and by the presence of six instead of seven ventral spine pairs on tibiae I and II ( Fig. 1A, B ). The single female, possessing 6–7 prolateral and retrolateral ventral spines on tibiae I and II, as well as an epigyne with median, anteriorly converging dark ridges, was described as
C. unicolor Simon, 1903
( Fig. 8A, B, E ). In that same year (1903b), Simon placed
Coryssiphus
in his concept of Clubionidae : Liocraninae and designated
C. praeustus
as the type species.
also listed the genus in Clubionidae : Liocraninae.

raised Liocraninae to family rank within what he delimited as Amaurobioidea. However,
, who erroneously attributed the type species designation to
, commented on
Coryssiphus
: “Transferred here outside Amaurobioidea, but its position remains unknown”. Nevertheless, all subsequent literature has classified
Coryssiphus
in Liocranidae , a family that belongs within Amaurobioidea.
listed the genus in Liocranidae incertae sedis , based on “some rather vague remarks” by
. Because there is no subsequent work on
Coryssiphus , Platnick (1989)
also listed the genus in Liocranidae , where it has resided to the present day (
).

The examination of Simon’s types in the present study shows that
Coryssiphus
is not a liocranid, but belongs to Miturgidae : Systariinae, as defined in
. The genus shares many characteristics with
Systaria Simon, 1897
. Moreover, additional specimens from the collections in MRAC, NCA and NMSA allowed the deduction that
C. unicolor
is conspecific with
C. cinerascens
, reducing the number of species in this enigmatic genus to two.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
Specimens were observed, photographed and drawn using Euromex MIC465 and Olympus SZX9 binocular microscopes. Tarsal claws and vulvae (cleared in methyl salicylate) were observed, photographed and drawn using a Wild M12 compound microscope. Stereomicroscope photographs were also made with Praktica DC42 or Sony NEX-5 digital cameras and, in case of multiple focus photographs, the image series obtained was stacked with Zerene Stacker version 1.04 build T 2023-06-11 -1120. Stacking photographs of the habitus of the type specimens were taken with a DFC500 camera mounted on a Leica MZ16 and piloted with the Leica Application Suite (LAS) stacking software (ver. 4.13; Leica, https://leicacamera.com), with a Z-stack of 15–20 images merged into a single photomontage. The colour drawing of the male of
C. praeustus
was rendered with an Aerograph Devilbiss Super 63 E airbrush.

Diagnosis.
Coryssiphus
is vaguely similar to
Arabelia Bosselaers, 2009
and
Drassinella Banks, 1904
by the absence of C, MA and other tegular apophyses in the male palp (
). For the same reason, it differs from all other Liocranidae . Moreover, it differs from
Liocranum L. Koch, 1866
,
Mesiotelus Simon, 1897
and
Hesperocranum Ubick & Platnick, 1991
by the parallel tapeta in the PME (
) and the absence of ventrolateral erectile bristles on the anterior legs ( Ubick & Platnick 1991 ).
Coryssiphus
differs from
Arabelia
and
Drassinella
by the shape of the male palpal bulbus, which is circular in ventral view instead of oval, by the long and basally inserted embolus, and by the short and simple ID. It differs from
Systaria Simon, 1897
( Miturgidae : Systariinae) by the somewhat smaller AME, stronger vsp on ti and mt I and II, trochanters that are only weakly notched, and a vulva with anterior CO (
).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Study of the available specimens shows that the genus
Coryssiphus
encompasses two species with a discrete size range ( Table 1 ) and subtle but clear differences in the genitalia. The larger species,
C. praeustus
, has longer, more slender front legs, a considerably longer and more slender male palpal tibia ( Figs 3C , 4A, B ), a longer cymbium relative to the bulbus ( Tables 1 , 2 ), an epigyne with a bell-shaped instead of trapezoidal central depression ( Figs 4C , 6B , 7C ), and ST2 that are oriented longitudinally instead of antero-laterally, as in
C. cinerascens
( Figs 6A , 7E ). The female of
C. praeustus
is described here for the first time. Simon’s small-sized
C. unicolor
turns out to be the female of
C. cinerascens
.

It must be admitted that the affinities and composition of Systariinae are still debated (
;
). The occurrence of Systariinae in Africa is puzzling, as the subfamily was only known from Southeast Asia prior to this study (
;
). However, comparable disjunct distributions have been observed in other taxa. The eleven species in the spider genus
Medmassa Simon, 1887
are all known from Southeast Asia and Australia , except
M. semiaurantiaca Simon, 1909
, which is only known from scattered locations spread over Africa (
). In the jumping spider genus
Depreissia Lessert, 1942
, the type species,
D. myrmex Lessert, 1942
, is only known from Congo , while the only other species in the genus,
D. decipiens Deeleman-Reinhold & Floren, 2003
is only known from Borneo. The zodariid
Tropizodium peregrinum Jocqué & Churchill, 2005
has an extremely disjunct distribution, only being known from Australia and Réunion Island (
).
Vytfutia Deeleman-Reinhold, 1986
includes three species from Southeast Asia, whereas the fourth species,
V. halandrefana Griswold, 2022
, lives in Madagascar .
hypothesized that this species may have reached Madagascar by “island hopping” from Southeast Asia to Madagascar .
proposed a similar mechanism to explain the presence of the salticid genus
Padilla Peckham & Peckham, 1894
in Madagascar .

A number of cases lend support to this hypothesis.
mention the presence of the Southeast Asian
Palicanus caudatus Thorell, 1897
, also a systariine, and
Orthobula impressa Simon, 1897
( Trachelidae ) on the Seychelles and Réunion , islands located in an intermediate position between Southeast Asia and Africa. The Calicnemiinae ( Odonata : Platycnemididae ) are represented by the vast majority of their genera in Southeast Asia, but five genera have at least one representative in the Seychelles , Madagascar or mainland Africa (
).

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
The collection curators mentioned above are gratefully acknowledged for providing the specimens used in this research. Rudy Jocqué is also thanked for invaluable help in locating the RMCA specimens and for taking the habitus photographs of the
Coryssiphus
holotypes . Special thanks are due to Martín Ramirez for being the first person to draw the author’s attention to the fact that
Coryssiphus
belongs in Systariinae, an attribution confirmed by Christa Deeleman-Reinhold in discussions. The author is very much indebted to Christa too, for long and interesting exchanges of information over a delicious bowl of soup. Norman Platnick is thanked for fruitful discussions on the genus. The author is especially grateful to Charles Haddad for continued support and advice and for freely providing good photographs and additional information on
Coryssiphus
specimens from South Africa . Thanks are also due to the referees, Ansie Dippenaar-Schoeman and Arnaud Henrard, who provided useful comments helping to improve the manuscript.
